\LetLtxMacro\oldtextsc

Latent Abstractions in Generative Diffusion Models

Giulio Franzese1, Mattia Martini2, Giulio Corallo1,3, Paolo Papotti 1, Pietro Michiardi1
1 Department of Data Science, EURECOM, Biot, France,
2 Université Côte d’Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire J. A. Dieudonné , Nice, France
3 SAP Labs, Mougins, France
Abstract

In this work we study how diffusion-based generative models produce high-dimensional data, such as an image, by implicitly relying on a manifestation of a low-dimensional set of latent abstractions, that guide the generative process. We present a novel theoretical framework that extends Nonlinear Filtering (\oldtextscnlf), and that offers a unique perspective on \oldtextscsde-based generative models. The development of our theory relies on a novel formulation of the joint (state and measurement) dynamics, and an information-theoretic measure of the influence of the system state on the measurement process. According to our theory, diffusion models can be cast as a system of \oldtextscsde, describing a non-linear filter in which the evolution of unobservable latent abstractions steers the dynamics of an observable measurement process (corresponding to the generative pathways). In addition, we present an empirical study to validate our theory and previous empirical results on the emergence of latent abstractions at different stages of the generative process.

1 Introduction

Generative models have become a cornerstone of modern machine learning, offering powerful methods for synthesizing high-quality data across various domains such as image and video synthesis (Dhariwal & Nichol, 2021; Ho et al., 2022; He et al., 2022), natural language processing (Li et al., 2022b; He et al., 2023; Gulrajani & Hashimoto, 2023; Lou et al., 2024), audio generation (Kong et al., 2021; Liu et al., 2022), and molecular structures and general 3D shapes (Trippe et al., 2022; Hoogeboom et al., 2022; Luo & Hu, 2021; Zeng et al., 2022), to name a few. These models transform an initial distribution, which is simple to sample from, into one that approximates the data distribution. Among these, diffusion-based models designed through the lenses of Stochastic Differential Equations (\oldtextscsdes) (Song et al., 2021; Ho et al., 2020; Albergo et al., 2023) have gained popularity due to their ability to generate realistic and diverse data samples through a series of stochastic transformations.

In such models, the data generation process, as described by a substantial body of empirical research (Chen et al., 2023; Linhardt et al., 2024; Tang et al., 2023), appears to develop according to distinct stages: high-level semantics emerge first, followed by the incorporation of low-level details, culminating in a refinement (denoising) phase. Despite ample evidence, a comprehensive theoretical framework for modeling these dynamics remains underexplored. Indeed, despite recent work on \oldtextscsde-based generative models (Berner et al., 2022; Richter & Berner, 2023; Ye et al., 2022; Raginsky, 2024) shed new lights on such models, they fall short of explicitly investigating the emergence of abstract representations in the generative process. We address this gap by establishing a new framework for elucidating how generative models construct and leverage latent abstractions, approached through the paradigm of \oldtextscnlf (Bain & Crisan, 2009; Van Handel, 2007; Kutschireiter et al., 2020).

\oldtextscnlf is used across diverse engineering domains (Bain & Crisan, 2009), as it provides robust methodologies for the estimation and prediction of a system’s state amidst uncertainty and noise. \oldtextscnlf enables the inference of dynamic latent variables that define the system state based on observed data, offering a Bayesian interpretation of state evolution and the ability to incorporate stochastic system dynamics. The problem we consider is the following: an unobservable random variable X𝑋Xitalic_X is measured through a noisy continuous-time process Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, wherein the influence of X𝑋Xitalic_X on the noisy process is described by an observation function H𝐻Hitalic_H, with the noise component modeled as a Brownian motion term. The goal is to estimate the a-posteriori measure πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the variable X𝑋Xitalic_X given the entire historical trajectory of the measurement process Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In this work, we establish a connection between \oldtextscsde-based generative models and \oldtextscnlf by observing that they can be interpreted as simulations of \oldtextscnlf dynamics. In our framework, the latent abstraction, which corresponds to certain real-world properties within the scope of classical nonlinear filtering and remains unaffected in a causal manner by the posterior process πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is implicitly simulated and iteratively refined. We explore the connection between latent abstractions and the a-posteriori process, through the concept of filtrations – broadly defined as collections of progressively increasing information sets – and offer a rigorous theory to study the emergence and influence of latent abstractions throughout the data generation process. Our theoretical contributions unfold as follows.

In § 2 we show how to reformulate classical \oldtextscnlf results such that the measurement process is the only available information, and derive the corresponding dynamics of both the latent abstraction and the measurement process. These results are summarized in Theorem 2 and Theorem 3.

Given the new dynamics, in Theorem 4 we show how to estimate the a-posteriori measure of the \oldtextscnlf model, and present a novel derivation to compute the mutual information between the measurement process and random variables derived from a transformation of the latent abstractions in Theorem 5. Finally, we show in Theorem 6, that the a-posteriori measure is a sufficient statistics for any random variable derived from the latent abstractions, when only having access to the measurement process.

Building on these general results, in § 3 we present a novel perspective on continuous-time score-based diffusion models, which is summarised in Equation 10. We propose to view such generative models as \oldtextscnlf simulators that progress in two stages: first our model updates the a-posteriori measure representing a sufficient statistics of the latent abstractions, second, it uses a projection of the a-posteriori measure to update the measurement process. Such intuitive understanding is the result of several fundamental steps. In Theorem 7 and Theorem 8, we show that the common view of score-based diffusion models by which they evolve according to forward (noising) and backward (generative) dynamics is compatible with the \oldtextscnlf formulation, in which there is no need to distinguish between such phases. In other words, the \oldtextscnlf perspective of Equation 10 is a valid generative model. In Appendix H, we provide additional results (see Lemma 1), focusing on the specific case of linear diffusion models, which are the most popular instance of score-based generative models in use today. In § 4, we summarize the main intuitions behind our \oldtextscnlf framework.

Our results explain, by means of a theoretically sound framework, the emergence of latent abstractions that has been observed by a large body of empirical work (Bisk et al., 2020; Bender & Koller, 2020; Li et al., 2022a; Park et al., 2023; Kwon et al., 2023; Chen et al., 2023; Linhardt et al., 2024; Tang et al., 2023; Xiang et al., 2023; Haas et al., 2024). The closest research to our findings is discussed in (Sclocchi et al., 2024), albeit from a different mathematical perspective. To root our theoretical results in additional empirical evidence, we conclude our work in § 5 with a series of experiments on score-based generative models (Song et al., 2021), where we 1) validate existing probing techniques to measure the emergence of latent abstractions, 2) compute the mutual information as derived in our framework, and show that it is a suitable approach to measure the relation between the generative process and latent abstractions, 3) introduce a new measurement protocol to further confirm the connections between our theory, and how practical diffusion-based generative models operate.

2 Nonlinear Filtering

Consider two random variables Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and X𝑋Xitalic_X, corresponding to a stochastic measurement process (Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) of some underlying latent abstraction (X𝑋Xitalic_X). We construct our universe sample space ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω as the combination of the space of continuous functions in the interval [0,T]0𝑇[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ] (T∈ℝ+𝑇superscriptℝT\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_T ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) and of a complete separable metric space 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S, i.e., Ω=𝒞⁢([0,T],ℝN)×𝒮Ω𝒞0𝑇superscriptℝ𝑁𝒮\Omega=\mathcal{C}([0,T],\mathbb{R}^{N})\times\mathcal{S}roman_Ω = caligraphic_C ( [ 0 , italic_T ] , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) × caligraphic_S. On this space, we consider the joint canonical process Zt⁢(ω)=[Yt,X]=[ωty,ωx]subscript𝑍𝑡𝜔subscript𝑌𝑡𝑋superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑦superscript𝜔𝑥Z_{t}(\omega)=[Y_{t},X]=[\omega_{t}^{y},\omega^{x}]italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ω ) = [ italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X ] = [ italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ω start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] for all ω∈Ω𝜔Ω\omega\in\Omegaitalic_ω ∈ roman_Ω, with ω=[ωy,ωx]𝜔superscript𝜔𝑦superscript𝜔𝑥\omega=[\omega^{y},\omega^{x}]italic_ω = [ italic_ω start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ω start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]. In this work we indicate with σ⁢(⋅)𝜎⋅\sigma(\cdot)italic_σ ( ⋅ ) sigma-algebras. Consider the growing filtration naturally induced by the canonical process ℱtY,X=σ⁢(Y0≤s≤t,X)subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑋𝑡𝜎subscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡𝑋\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}_{t}=\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t},X)caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X ) (a short-hand for σ⁢(σ⁢(Y0≤s≤t)∪σ⁢(X))𝜎𝜎subscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡𝜎𝑋\sigma(\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t})\cup\sigma(X))italic_σ ( italic_σ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∪ italic_σ ( italic_X ) )), and define ℱ=ℱTY,Xℱsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑋𝑇\mathcal{F}=\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}_{T}caligraphic_F = caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.We build the probability triplet (Ω,ℱ,P)ΩℱP(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Ω , caligraphic_F , roman_P ), where the probability measure PP\mathrm{P}roman_P is selected such that the process {Z0≤t≤T,ℱ0≤t≤TY,X}subscript𝑍0𝑡𝑇subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑋0𝑡𝑇\{Z_{0\leq t\leq T},\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}_{0\leq t\leq T}\}{ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } has the following \oldtextscsde representation

Yt=Y0+∫0tH⁢(Ys,X,s)⁢ds+Wt,subscript𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌0superscriptsubscript0𝑡𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠𝑋𝑠𝑠subscript𝑊𝑡Y_{t}=Y_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}H(Y_{s},X,s)\differential s+W_{t},italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X , italic_s ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (1)

where {W0≤t≤T,ℱ0≤t≤TY,X}subscript𝑊0𝑡𝑇subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑋0𝑡𝑇\{W_{0\leq t\leq T},\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}_{0\leq t\leq T}\}{ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is a Brownian motion with initial value 0 and H:Ω×[0,T]→ℝN:𝐻→Ω0𝑇superscriptℝ𝑁H:\Omega\times[0,T]\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{N}italic_H : roman_Ω × [ 0 , italic_T ] → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an observation process. All standard technical assumptions are available in Appendix A.

Next, we provide the necessary background on \oldtextscnlf, to pave the way for understanding its connection with the generative models of interest. The most important building block of the \oldtextscnlf literature is represented by the conditional probability measure P⁢[X∈A|ℱtY]Pdelimited-[]𝑋conditional𝐴subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathrm{P}[X\in A\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]roman_P [ italic_X ∈ italic_A | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] (notice the reduced filtration ℱtY⊂ℱtY,Xsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑋𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}\subset\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), which summarizes, a-posteriori, the distribution of X𝑋Xitalic_X given observations of the measurement process until time t𝑡titalic_t, that is, Y0≤s≤tsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡Y_{0\leq s\leq t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Theorem 1.

[Thm 2.1 (Bain & Crisan, 2009)] Consider the probability triplet (Ω,ℱ,P)ΩℱP(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Ω , caligraphic_F , roman_P ), the metric space 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S and its Borel sigma-algebra ℬ⁢(𝒮)ℬ𝒮\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{S})caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_S ). There exists a (probability measure valued 𝒫⁢(𝒮)𝒫𝒮\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{S})caligraphic_P ( caligraphic_S )) process {π0≤t≤T,ℱ0≤t≤TY}subscript𝜋0𝑡𝑇subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌0𝑡𝑇\{{{\pi}}_{0\leq t\leq T},\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{0\leq t\leq T}\}{ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, with a progressively measurable modification, such that for all A∈ℬ⁢(𝒮)𝐴ℬ𝒮A\in\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{S})italic_A ∈ caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_S ), the conditional probability measure P⁢[X∈A|ℱtY]Pdelimited-[]𝑋conditional𝐴subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathrm{P}[X\in A\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]roman_P [ italic_X ∈ italic_A | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is well defined and is equal to πt⁢(A)subscript𝜋𝑡𝐴{{\pi}_{t}}(A)italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ).

The conditional probability measure is extremely important, as the fundamental goal of nonlinear filtering is the solution of the following problem. Here, we introduce the quantity ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, which is a random variable derived from the latent abstractions X𝑋Xitalic_X.

Problem 1.

For any fixed ϕ:𝒮→ℝ:italic-ϕ→𝒮ℝ\phi:\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}italic_ϕ : caligraphic_S → blackboard_R bounded and measurable, given knowledge of the measurement process Y0≤s≤tsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡Y_{0\leq s\leq t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, compute 𝔼P⁢[ϕ⁢(X)|ℱtY]subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]conditionalitalic-ϕ𝑋subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\phi(X)\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_ϕ ( italic_X ) | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. This amounts to computing

⟨πt,ϕ⟩=∫𝒮ϕ⁢(x)⁢dπt⁢(x).subscript𝜋𝑡italic-ϕsubscript𝒮italic-ϕ𝑥subscript𝜋𝑡𝑥\langle{{\pi}_{t}},\phi\rangle=\int_{\mathcal{S}}\phi(x)\differential{{\pi}_{t% }}(x).⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ ⟩ = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ ( italic_x ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) . (2)

In simple terms, 1 involves studying the existence of the a-posteriori measure and the implementation of efficient algorithms for its update, using the flowing stream of incoming information Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We first focus our attention on the existence of an analytic expression for the value of the a-posteriori expected measure πtsubscript𝜋𝑡{{\pi}_{t}}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, we quantify the interaction dynamics between observable measurements and ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, through the lenses of mutual information ℐ⁢(Y0≤s≤t;ϕ)ℐsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡italic-ϕ\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ ), which is an extension of the problems considered in (Newton, 2008; Duncan, 1970; 1971; Mitter & Newton, 2003).

2.1 Technical preliminaries

We set the stage of our work by revisiting the measurement process Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and express it in a way that does not require access to unobservable information. Indeed, while Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is naturally adapted w.r.t. its own filtration ℱtYsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and consequently to any other growing filtration ℛtsubscriptℛ𝑡\mathcal{R}_{t}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such ℱtY,X⊇ℛt⊇ℱtYsuperset-of-or-equalssubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑋𝑡subscriptℛ𝑡superset-of-or-equalssubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}_{t}\supseteq\mathcal{R}_{t}\supseteq\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊇ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊇ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the representation in Equation 1 is in general not adapted, letting aside degenerate cases.

Let’s consider the family of growing filtrations ℛt=σ⁢(ℛ0∪σ⁢(Y0≤s≤t−Y0))subscriptℛ𝑡𝜎subscriptℛ0𝜎subscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡subscript𝑌0\mathcal{R}_{t}=\sigma(\mathcal{R}_{0}\cup\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t}-Y_{0}))caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ italic_σ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), where σ⁢(Y0)⊆ℛ0⊆σ⁢(X,Y0)𝜎subscript𝑌0subscriptℛ0𝜎𝑋subscript𝑌0\sigma(Y_{0})\subseteq\mathcal{R}_{0}\subseteq\sigma(X,Y_{0})italic_σ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⊆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ italic_σ ( italic_X , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Intuitively ℛ0subscriptℛ0\mathcal{R}_{0}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT allows to modulate between the two extreme cases of knowing only the initial conditions of the \oldtextscsde, that is Y0subscript𝑌0Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, to the case of complete knowledge of the whole latent abstraction X𝑋Xitalic_X, and anything in between. As shown hereafter, the original process Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT associated to the space (Ω,ℱ,P)ΩℱP(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Ω , caligraphic_F , roman_P ) which solves Equation 1, also solves Equation 4, that is adapted on the reduced filtration ℛtsubscriptℛ𝑡\mathcal{R}_{t}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This allows us to reason about the partial observation of the latent abstraction (ℛ0subscriptℛ0\mathcal{R}_{0}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT vs σ⁢(X,Y0)𝜎𝑋subscript𝑌0\sigma(X,Y_{0})italic_σ ( italic_X , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )), without incurring in the problem of the measurement process Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being statistically dependent of the whole latent abstraction X𝑋Xitalic_X.

Armed with such representation, we study under which change of measure the process Yt−Y0subscript𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌0Y_{t}-Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT behaves as a Brownian motion (Theorem 3). This serves the purpose of simplifying the calculation of the expected value of ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ given Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as described in 1. Indeed, if Yt−Y0subscript𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌0Y_{t}-Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Brownian motion independent of ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, its knowledge does not influence our best guess for ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, i.e. the conditional expected value. Moreover, our alternative representation is instrumental for the efficient and simple computation of the mutual information ℐ⁢(Y0≤s≤t;ϕ)ℐsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡italic-ϕ\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ ), where the different measures involved in the Radon-Nikodym derivatives will be compared against the same reference Brownian measures.

The first step to define our representation is provided by the following

Theorem 2.

[Proof]. Consider the the probability triplet (Ω,ℱ,P)ΩℱP(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Ω , caligraphic_F , roman_P ), the process in Equation 1 defined on it, and the growing filtration ℛt=σ⁢(ℛ0∪σ⁢(Y0≤s≤t−Y0))subscriptℛ𝑡𝜎subscriptℛ0𝜎subscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡subscript𝑌0\mathcal{R}_{t}=\sigma(\mathcal{R}_{0}\cup\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t}-Y_{0}))caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ italic_σ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). Next, we derive the change of measure necessary for the process W~t=defYt−Y0superscriptdefsubscript~𝑊𝑡subscript𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌0\tilde{W}_{t}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}Y_{t}-Y_{0}over~ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be a Brownian motion w.r.t to the filtration ℛtsubscriptℛ𝑡\mathcal{R}_{t}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
