Theorem 3.

[Proof]. Define the new probability space (Ω,ℛT,Qℛ)Ωsubscriptℛ𝑇superscriptQℛ(\Omega,\mathcal{R}_{T},{\mathrm{Q}^{\mathcal{R}}})( roman_Ω , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) via the measure Qℛ⁢(A)=𝔼P⁢[𝟏⁢(A)⁢(ψTℛ)−1]superscriptQℛ𝐴subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]1𝐴superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜓ℛ𝑇1{\mathrm{Q}^{\mathcal{R}}}(A)=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}\left[\mathbf{1}(A)({\psi% ^{\mathcal{R}}_{T}})^{-1}\right]roman_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_A ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) ( italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], for A∈ℛT𝐴subscriptℛ𝑇A\in\mathcal{R}_{T}italic_A ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where

ψtℛ=defexp⁡(∫0t𝔼P⁢[H⁢(Ys,X,s)|ℛs]⁢dYs−12⁢∫0t‖𝔼P⁢[H⁢(Ys,X,s)|ℛs]‖2⁢ds),superscriptdefsubscriptsuperscript𝜓ℛ𝑡superscriptsubscript0𝑡subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]conditional𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠𝑋𝑠subscriptℛ𝑠subscript𝑌𝑠12superscriptsubscript0𝑡superscriptnormsubscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]conditional𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠𝑋𝑠subscriptℛ𝑠2𝑠\psi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\exp(\int_{0}^{t% }\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[H(Y_{s},X,s)\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{s}]\differential Y_{s}-% \frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{t}\norm{\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[H(Y_{s},X,s)\,|\,\mathcal% {R}_{s}]}^{2}\differential s),italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP roman_exp ( start_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X , italic_s ) | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X , italic_s ) | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s end_ARG ) , (5)

and

Qℛ|ℛt=𝔼P⁢[𝟏⁢(A)⁢𝔼P⁢[(ψTℛ)−1|ℛt]]=𝔼P⁢[𝟏⁢(A)⁢(ψtℛ)−1].evaluated-atsuperscriptQℛsubscriptℛ𝑡subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]1𝐴subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜓ℛ𝑇1subscriptℛ𝑡subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]1𝐴superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜓ℛ𝑡1{\mathrm{Q}^{\mathcal{R}}}\,|\,_{\mathcal{R}_{t}}=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}\left% [\mathbf{1}(A)\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[({\psi^{\mathcal{R}}_{T}})^{-1}\,|\,% \mathcal{R}_{t}]\right]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}\left[\mathbf{1}(A)({\psi^{% \mathcal{R}}_{t}})^{-1}\right].roman_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ( italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) ( italic_ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] .

Then, the stochastic process {W~0≤t≤T,ℛ0≤t≤T}subscript~𝑊0𝑡𝑇subscriptℛ0𝑡𝑇\{\tilde{W}_{0\leq t\leq T},\mathcal{R}_{0\leq t\leq T}\}{ over~ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is a Brownian motion on the space (Ω,ℛT,Qℛ)Ωsubscriptℛ𝑇superscriptQℛ(\Omega,\mathcal{R}_{T},{\mathrm{Q}^{\mathcal{R}}})( roman_Ω , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

A direct consequence of Theorem 3 is that the process W~tsubscript~𝑊𝑡\tilde{W}_{t}over~ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent of any ℛ0subscriptℛ0\mathcal{R}_{0}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable random variable under the measure QℛsuperscriptQℛ{\mathrm{Q}^{\mathcal{R}}}roman_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, it holds that for all ℛt′⊆ℛtsubscriptsuperscriptℛ′𝑡subscriptℛ𝑡\mathcal{R}^{\prime}_{t}\subseteq\mathcal{R}_{t}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Qℛ|ℛt′=Qℛ′|ℛt′evaluated-atsuperscriptQℛsubscriptsuperscriptℛ′𝑡evaluated-atsuperscriptQsuperscriptℛ′subscriptsuperscriptℛ′𝑡{\mathrm{Q}^{\mathcal{R}}}\,|\,_{\mathcal{R}^{\prime}_{t}}=\mathrm{Q}^{% \mathcal{R}^{\prime}}\,|\,_{\mathcal{R}^{\prime}_{t}}roman_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

2.2 A-Posteriori Measure and Mutual Information

As we did in § 2 for the process πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, here we introduce a new process πtℛsubscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ𝑡\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which represents the conditional law of X𝑋Xitalic_X given the filtration ℛt=σ⁢(ℛ0∪σ⁢(Y0≤s≤t−Y0))subscriptℛ𝑡𝜎subscriptℛ0𝜎subscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡subscript𝑌0\mathcal{R}_{t}=\sigma(\mathcal{R}_{0}\cup\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t}-Y_{0}))caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ italic_σ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). More precisely, for all A∈ℬ⁢(𝒮)𝐴ℬ𝒮A\in\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{S})italic_A ∈ caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_S ), the conditional probability measure P⁢[X∈A|ℛt]Pdelimited-[]𝑋conditional𝐴subscriptℛ𝑡\mathrm{P}[X\in A\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{t}]roman_P [ italic_X ∈ italic_A | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is well defined and is equal to πtℛ⁢(A)subscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ𝑡𝐴\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}(A)italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ). Moreover, for any ϕ:𝒮→ℝ:italic-ϕ→𝒮ℝ\phi:\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}italic_ϕ : caligraphic_S → blackboard_R bounded and measurable, 𝔼P⁢[ϕ⁢(X)|ℛt]=⟨πtℛ,ϕ⟩subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]conditionalitalic-ϕ𝑋subscriptℛ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ𝑡italic-ϕ\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\phi(X)\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{t}]=\langle\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_% {t},\phi\rangleblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_ϕ ( italic_X ) | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = ⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ ⟩. Notice that if ℛ=ℱYℛsuperscriptℱ𝑌\mathcal{R}=\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_R = caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT then πℛsuperscript𝜋ℛ\pi^{\mathcal{R}}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT reduces to π𝜋\piitalic_π.

Armed with Theorem 3, we are ready to derive the expression for the a-posteriori measure πtℛsubscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ𝑡\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the mutual information between observable measurements and the unavailable information about the latent abstractions, that materialize in the random variable ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ.

Theorem 4.

[Proof]. The measure-valued process πtℛsubscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ𝑡\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT solves in weak sense (see Appendix D for a precise definition), the following \oldtextscsde

πtℛ=π0ℛ+∫0tπsℛ⁢(H⁢(Ys,⋅,s)−⟨πsℛ,H⁢(Ys,⋅,s)⟩)⁢(dYs−⟨πsℛ,H⁢(Ys,⋅,s)⟩⁢ds),subscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ0superscriptsubscript0𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ𝑠𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠⋅𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ𝑠𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠⋅𝑠subscript𝑌𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ𝑠𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠⋅𝑠𝑠\displaystyle\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}=\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\pi^{% \mathcal{R}}_{s}\left(H(Y_{s},\cdot,s)-\langle\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{s},H(Y_{s},% \cdot,s)\rangle\right)\left(\differential Y_{s}-\langle\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{s},H% (Y_{s},\cdot,s)\rangle\differential s\right),italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋅ , italic_s ) - ⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋅ , italic_s ) ⟩ ) ( start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋅ , italic_s ) ⟩ start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ) , (6)

where the initial condition π0subscript𝜋0\pi_{0}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies π0ℛ⁢(A)=P⁢[X∈A|ℛ0]subscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ0𝐴Pdelimited-[]𝑋conditional𝐴subscriptℛ0\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{0}(A)=\mathrm{P}[X\in A\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{0}]italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ) = roman_P [ italic_X ∈ italic_A | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] for all A∈ℬ⁢(𝒮)𝐴ℬ𝒮A\in\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{S})italic_A ∈ caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_S ).

When ℛ=ℱYℛsuperscriptℱ𝑌\mathcal{R}=\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_R = caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Equation 6 is the well-know Kushner-Stratonovitch (or Fujisaki-Kallianpur-Kunita) equation (see e.g. Bain & Crisan (2009)). A proof for uniqueness of the solution of Equation 6 can be approached by considering the strategies in (Fotsa-Mbogne & Pardoux, 2017), but is outside the scope of this work. The (recursive) expression in Equation 6 is particularly useful for engineering purposes since, in general, it is usually not known in which variables ϕ⁢(X)italic-ϕ𝑋\phi(X)italic_ϕ ( italic_X ), representing latent abstractions, we could be interested in. Keeping track of the whole distribution πtℛsubscriptsuperscript𝜋ℛ𝑡\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at time t𝑡titalic_t is the most cost-effective solution, as we will show later.

Our next goal is to quantify the interaction dynamics between observable measurements and latent abstractions that materialize through the variable ϕ⁢(X)italic-ϕ𝑋\phi(X)italic_ϕ ( italic_X ) (from now on we write only ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ for the sake of brevity): in Theorem 5 we derive the mutual information ℐ⁢(Y0≤s≤t;ϕ)ℐsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡italic-ϕ\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ ).

Theorem 5.

[Proof] The mutual information between observable measurements Y0≤s≤tsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡Y_{0\leq s\leq t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ is defined as:

ℐ⁢(Y0≤s≤t;ϕ)=def∫log⁡dP#⁢Y0≤s≤t,ϕdP#⁢Y0≤s≤t⁢dP#⁢ϕ⁢dP#⁢Y0≤s≤t,ϕ.superscriptdefℐsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡italic-ϕsubscriptP#subscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡italic-ϕsubscriptP#subscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡subscriptP#italic-ϕsubscriptP#subscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡italic-ϕ\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}% \int\log\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t},\phi}}{% \differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t}}\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#\phi}}% \differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t},\phi}.caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP ∫ roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_ϕ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (7)

It holds that such quantity is equal to 𝔼P⁢[log⁡dP|ℛtdP|ℱtY⁢dP|σ⁢(ϕ)]subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]evaluated-atPsubscriptℛ𝑡evaluated-atevaluated-atPsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡P𝜎italic-ϕ\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}\left[\log\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{% R}_{t}}}{\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}}\differential% \mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\sigma(\phi)}}\right]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ ( italic_ϕ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ], which can be simplified as follows:

ℐ⁢(Y0;ϕ)+12⁢𝔼P⁢[∫0t‖𝔼P⁢[H⁢(X,Ys,s)|ℱsY]−𝔼P⁢[H⁢(X,Ys,s)|ℛs]‖2⁢ds].ℐsubscript𝑌0italic-ϕ12subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0𝑡superscriptnormsubscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]conditional𝐻𝑋subscript𝑌𝑠𝑠subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑠subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]conditional𝐻𝑋subscript𝑌𝑠𝑠subscriptℛ𝑠2𝑠\mathcal{I}(Y_{0};\phi)+\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}\left[\int_{0}^{t}% \norm{\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[H(X,Y_{s},s)\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{s}]-\mathbb{E}% _{\mathrm{P}}[H(X,Y_{s},s)\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{s}]}^{2}\differential s\right].caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_H ( italic_X , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s ) | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_H ( italic_X , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s ) | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ] . (8)

The mutual information computed by Equation 8 is composed by two elements: first, the mutual information between the initial measurements Y0subscript𝑌0Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, which is typically zero by construction. The second term quantifies how much the best prediction of the observation function H𝐻Hitalic_H is influenced by the extra knowledge of ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, in addition to the measurement history Y0≤s≤tsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡Y_{0\leq s\leq t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By adhering to the premise that the conditional expectation of a stochastic variable constitutes the optimal estimator given the conditioning information, the integral on the r.h.s quantifies the expected square difference between predictions, having access to measurements only (𝔼P[⋅|ℱtY]\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\cdot\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ⋅ | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]) and those incorporating additional information (𝔼P[⋅|ℛt]\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\cdot\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{t}]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ⋅ | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]).

Even though a precise characterization for general observation functions and and variables ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ is typically out of reach, a qualitative analysis is possible. First, the mutual information between ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ and the measurements depends on i) how much the amplitude of H𝐻Hitalic_H is impacted by knowledge of ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ and ii) the number of elements of H𝐻Hitalic_H which are impacted (informally, how much localized vs global is the impact of ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ). Second, it is possible to define a hierarchical interpretation about the emergence of the various latent factors: a variable with a local impact can “appear”, in an information theoretic sense, only if the impact of other global variables is resolved, otherwise the remaining uncertainty of the global variables makes knowledge of the local variable irrelevant. In classical diffusion models, this is empirically known (Chen et al., 2023; Linhardt et al., 2024; Tang et al., 2023), and corresponds to the phenomenon where semantics emerges before details (global vs local details in our language).

Now, consider any ℱtYsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable random variable Y~tsubscript~𝑌𝑡\tilde{Y}_{t}over~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined as a mapping to a generic measurable space (Ψ,ℬ⁢(Ψ))ΨℬΨ(\Psi,\mathcal{B}(\Psi))( roman_Ψ , caligraphic_B ( roman_Ψ ) ), which means it can also be seen as a process. The data processing inequality states that the mutual information between such Y~~𝑌\tilde{Y}over~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG and ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ will be smaller than the mutual information between the original measurement process and ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ. However, it can be shown that all the relevant information about the random variable ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ contained in ℱtYsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is equivalently contained in the filtering process at time instant t𝑡titalic_t, that is πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is not trivial, since πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a ℱtYsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-measurable quantity, i.e., σ⁢(πt)⊂ℱtY𝜎subscript𝜋𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\sigma(\pi_{t})\subset\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}italic_σ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⊂ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In other words, we show that πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a sufficient statistic for any σ⁢(X)𝜎𝑋\sigma(X)italic_σ ( italic_X ) measurable random variable when starting from the measurement process.

Theorem 6.

[Proof] For any ℱtYsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable random variable Y~t:Ω→Ψ:subscript~𝑌𝑡→ΩΨ\tilde{Y}_{t}:\Omega\rightarrow\Psiover~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : roman_Ω → roman_Ψ, the following inequality holds:

ℐ⁢(Y~;ϕ)≤ℐ⁢(Y0≤s≤t;ϕ).ℐ~𝑌italic-ϕℐsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡italic-ϕ\mathcal{I}(\tilde{Y};\phi)\leq\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi).caligraphic_I ( over~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG ; italic_ϕ ) ≤ caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ ) . (9)

For a given t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0italic_t ≥ 0, the measurement process Y0≤s≤tsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡Y_{0\leq s\leq t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and X𝑋Xitalic_X are conditionally-independent given πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This implies that P⁢(A|σ⁢(πt))=P⁢(A|ℱtY),∀A∈σ⁢(X)formulae-sequencePconditional𝐴𝜎subscript𝜋𝑡Pconditional𝐴subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡for-all𝐴𝜎𝑋\mathrm{P}(A\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t}))=\mathrm{P}(A\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}),\quad% \forall A\in\sigma(X)roman_P ( italic_A | italic_σ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = roman_P ( italic_A | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ∀ italic_A ∈ italic_σ ( italic_X ). Then ℐ⁢(Y0≤s≤t;ϕ)=ℐ⁢(πt;ϕ)ℐsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡italic-ϕℐsubscript𝜋𝑡italic-ϕ\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)=\mathcal{I}(\pi_{t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ ) = caligraphic_I ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ ) (i.e. Equation 9 is attained with equality).

While πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains all the relevant information about ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, the same cannot be said about the conditional expectation, i.e. the particular case Y~=⟨πt,ϕ⟩~𝑌subscript𝜋𝑡italic-ϕ\tilde{Y}=\langle\pi_{t},\phi\rangleover~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG = ⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ ⟩. Indeed, from Equation 2, ⟨πt,ϕ⟩subscript𝜋𝑡italic-ϕ\langle\pi_{t},\phi\rangle⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ ⟩ is obtained as a transformation of πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and thus can be interpreted as a ℱtYsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable quantity subject to the constraint of Equation 9. As a particular case, the quantity ⟨πt,H⟩subscript𝜋𝑡𝐻\langle{{\pi}_{t}},H\rangle⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H ⟩, of central importance in the construction of generative models § 3, carries in general less information about ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ than the un-projected πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3 Generative Modelling

We are interested in generative models for a given σ⁢(X)𝜎𝑋\sigma(X)italic_σ ( italic_X )-measurable random variable V𝑉Vitalic_V. An intuitive illustration of how data generation works according to our framework is as follows. Consider, for example, the image domain, and the availability of a rendering engine that takes as an input a computer program describing a scene (coordinates of objects, textures, light sources, auxiliary labels, etc …) and that produces an output image of the scene. In a similar vein, a generative model learns how to use latent variables (which are not explicitly provided in input, but rather implicitly learned through training) to generate an image. For such model to work, one valid strategy is to consider an \oldtextscsde in the form of Equation 1 where the following holds111 From a strict technical point of view, 1 might be incompatible with other assumptions in Appendix A, or proving compatibility could require particular effort. Such details are discussed in Appendix G. .

Assumption 1.

The stochastic process Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies YT=V,P−a.s.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑌𝑇𝑉P𝑎𝑠Y_{T}=V,\quad\mathrm{P}-a.s.italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V , roman_P - italic_a . italic_s .

Then, we could numerically simulate the dynamics of Equation 1 until time T𝑇Titalic_T. Indeed, starting from initial conditions Y0subscript𝑌0Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we could obtain YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that, under 1, is precisely V𝑉Vitalic_V. Unfortunately, such a simple idea requires explicit access to X𝑋Xitalic_X, as it is evident from Equation 1. In mathematical terms, Equation 1 is adapted to the filtration ℱtY,Xsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑋𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, we have shown how to reduce the available information to account only for historical values of Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, we can combine the result in Theorem 4 with Theorem 2 and re-interpret Equation 4, which is a valid generative model, as

{πt=π0+∫0tπs⁢(H−⟨πs,H⟩)⁢(dYs−⟨πs,H⟩⁢ds),Yt=Y0+∫0t⟨πs,H⟩⁢ds+WtℱY,casessubscript𝜋𝑡subscript𝜋0superscriptsubscript0𝑡subscript𝜋𝑠𝐻subscript𝜋𝑠𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠subscript𝜋𝑠𝐻𝑠otherwisesubscript𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌0superscriptsubscript0𝑡subscript𝜋𝑠𝐻𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑊superscriptℱ𝑌𝑡otherwise\begin{cases}\pi_{t}=\pi_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\pi_{s}\left(H-\langle{{\pi}_{s}},H% \rangle\right)\left(\differential Y_{s}-\langle{{\pi}_{s}},H\rangle% \differential s\right),\\ Y_{t}=Y_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\langle{{\pi}_{s}},H\rangle\differential s+{W}^{% \mathcal{F}^{Y}}_{t},\end{cases}{ start_ROW start_CELL italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H - ⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H ⟩ ) ( start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H ⟩ start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ) , end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H ⟩ start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW (10)

where H𝐻Hitalic_H denotes H⁢(Ys,⋅,s)𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠⋅𝑠H(Y_{s},\cdot,s)italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋅ , italic_s ). Explicit simulation of Equation 10 only requires knowledge of the whole history of the measurement process: provided 1 holds, it allows generation of a sample of the random variable V𝑉Vitalic_V.

Although the discussion in this work includes a large class of observation functions, we focus on the particular case of generative diffusion models (Song et al., 2021). Typically, such models are presented through the lenses of a forward noising process and backward (in time) \oldtextscsdes, following the intuition of Anderson (1982). Next, according to the framework we introduce in this work, we reinterpret such models under the perspective of enlargement of filtrations.

Consider the reversed process Y^t=defYT−tsuperscriptdefsubscript^𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌𝑇𝑡\hat{Y}_{t}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}Y_{T-t}over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defined on (Ω,ℱ,P)ΩℱP(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Ω , caligraphic_F , roman_P ) and the corresponding filtration ℱtY^=defσ⁢(Y^0≤s≤t)superscriptdefsuperscriptsubscriptℱ𝑡^𝑌𝜎subscript^𝑌0𝑠𝑡\mathcal{F}_{t}^{\hat{Y}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\sigma(\hat{Y% }_{0\leq s\leq t})caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_σ ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The measure PP\mathrm{P}roman_P is selected such that the process Y^tsubscript^𝑌𝑡\hat{Y}_{t}over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has ℱtY^superscriptsubscriptℱ𝑡^𝑌\mathcal{F}_{t}^{\hat{Y}}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT–adapted expression

Y^t=V+∫0tF⁢(Y^s,s)⁢ds+W^t,subscript^𝑌𝑡𝑉superscriptsubscript0𝑡𝐹subscript^𝑌𝑠𝑠𝑠subscript^𝑊𝑡\hat{Y}_{t}=V+\int\limits_{0}^{t}F(\hat{Y}_{s},s)\differential s+\hat{W}_{t},over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (11)

where {W^t,ℱtY^}subscript^𝑊𝑡superscriptsubscriptℱ𝑡^𝑌\{\hat{W}_{t},\mathcal{F}_{t}^{\hat{Y}}\}{ over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } is a Brownian motion. Then, 1 is valid since YT=Y^0=Vsubscript𝑌𝑇subscript^𝑌0𝑉Y_{T}=\hat{Y}_{0}=Vitalic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V. Note that Equation 11, albeit with a different notation, is reminiscent of the forward \oldtextscsde that is typically used as the starting point to illustrate score-based generative models (Song et al., 2021). In particular, F⁢(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot)italic_F ( ⋅ ) corresponds to the drift term of such a diffusion \oldtextscsde.

Equation 11 is equivalent to Yt=V+∫tTF⁢(Ys,T−s)⁢ds+W^T−tsubscript𝑌𝑡𝑉superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑇𝐹subscript𝑌𝑠𝑇𝑠𝑠subscript^𝑊𝑇𝑡Y_{t}=V+\int\limits_{t}^{T}F(Y_{s},T-s)\differential s+\hat{W}_{T-t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is an expression for the process Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is adapted to ℱY^superscriptℱ^𝑌\mathcal{F}^{\hat{Y}}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This constitutes the first step to derive an equivalent backward (generative) process according to the traditional framework of score-based diffusion models. Note that such an equivalent representation is not useful for simulation purposes: the goals of the next steps is to transform it such that it is adapted to ℱYsuperscriptℱ𝑌\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Indeed, using simple algebra, it holds that

Yt=Y0−∫0tF⁢(Ys,T−s)⁢ds+(−Y0+V+∫0TF⁢(Ys,T−s)⁢ds+W^T−t),subscript𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌0superscriptsubscript0𝑡𝐹subscript𝑌𝑠𝑇𝑠𝑠subscript𝑌0𝑉superscriptsubscript0𝑇𝐹subscript𝑌𝑠𝑇𝑠𝑠subscript^𝑊𝑇𝑡Y_{t}=Y_{0}-\int\limits_{0}^{t}F(Y_{s},T-s)\differential s+\left(-Y_{0}+V+\int% \limits_{0}^{T}F(Y_{s},T-s)\differential s+\hat{W}_{T-t}\right),italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + ( - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_V + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where the last term in the parentheses is equal to −W^T+W^T−tsubscript^𝑊𝑇subscript^𝑊𝑇𝑡-\hat{W}_{T}+\hat{W}_{T-t}- over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Note that ℱtY=σ⁢(Y^T−t≤s≤T)superscriptsubscriptℱ𝑡𝑌𝜎subscript^𝑌𝑇𝑡𝑠𝑇\mathcal{F}_{t}^{Y}=\sigma(\hat{Y}_{T-t\leq s\leq T})caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_σ ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Since σ⁢(Y^T−t≤s≤T)=σ⁢(W^T−t≤s≤T)∪σ⁢(Y^T−t)𝜎subscript^𝑌𝑇𝑡𝑠𝑇𝜎subscript^𝑊𝑇𝑡𝑠𝑇𝜎subscript^𝑌𝑇𝑡\sigma(\hat{Y}_{T-t\leq s\leq T})=\sigma(\hat{W}_{T-t\leq s\leq T})\cup\sigma(% \hat{Y}_{T-t})italic_σ ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_σ ( over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∪ italic_σ ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we can apply the result in (Pardoux, 2006) (Thm 2.2) to claim the following: −W^T+W^T−t−∫0t∇log⁡p^⁢(Ys,T−s)⁢dssubscript^𝑊𝑇subscript^𝑊𝑇𝑡superscriptsubscript0𝑡∇^𝑝subscript𝑌𝑠𝑇𝑠𝑠-\hat{W}_{T}+\hat{W}_{T-t}-\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\log\hat{p}(Y_{s},T-s)\differential s- over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ roman_log over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s is a Brownian motion adapted to ℱtYsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where this time P⁢(Y^t∈dy)=p^⁢(y,t)⁢dyPsubscript^𝑌𝑡𝑦^𝑝𝑦𝑡𝑦\mathrm{P}(\hat{Y}_{t}\in\differential y)=\hat{p}(y,t)\differential yroman_P ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y ) = over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( italic_y , italic_t ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y. Then (Pardoux, 2006)

Theorem 7.

Consider the stochastic process Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which solves Equation 11. The same stochastic process also admits a ℱtYsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT–adapted representation

Yt=Y0+∫0t−F⁢(Ys,T−s)+∇log⁡p^⁢(Ys,T−s)⏟In Theorem 8,we call this ⁢F′⁢(Ys,s)⁢ds+Wt.subscript𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌0superscriptsubscript0𝑡subscript⏟𝐹subscript𝑌𝑠𝑇𝑠∇^𝑝subscript𝑌𝑠𝑇𝑠In Theorem 8,we call this superscript𝐹′subscript𝑌𝑠𝑠𝑠subscript𝑊𝑡Y_{t}=Y_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\underbrace{-F(Y_{s},T-s)+\nabla\log\hat{p}(Y_{s},T-s)% }_{\text{In \lx@cref{creftypecap~refnum}{theo:connection},we call this }F^{% \prime}(Y_{s},s)}\differential s+W_{t}.italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT under⏟ start_ARG - italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) + ∇ roman_log over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT In ,we call this italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (12)

Equation 12 corresponds to the backward diffusion process from (Song et al., 2021) and, because it is adapted to the filtration ℱYsuperscriptℱ𝑌\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, it represents a valid, and easy to simulate, measurement process.

By now, it is clear how to go from an ℱY,Xsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑋\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT–adapted filtration to a ℱYsuperscriptℱ𝑌\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT–adapted one. We also showed that a ℱYsuperscriptℱ𝑌\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT–adapted filtration can be linked to the reverse, ℱY^superscriptℱ^𝑌\mathcal{F}^{\hat{Y}}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT–adapted process induced by a forward diffusion \oldtextscsde. What remains to be discussed is the connection that exists between the ℱYsuperscriptℱ𝑌\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT–adapted filtration, and its enlarged version ℱY,Xsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑋\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In other words, we have shown that a forward, diffusion \oldtextscsde admits a backward process which is compatible with our generative model that simulates a \oldtextscnlf process having access only to measurements, but we need to make sure that such process admits a formulation that is compatible the standard \oldtextscnlf framework in which latent abstractions are available.

To do this, we can leverage existing results about Markovian bridges (Rogers & Williams, 2000; Ye et al., 2022) (and further work (Aksamit et al., 2017; Ouwehand, 2022; Grigorian & Jarrow, 2023; Çetin & Danilova, 2016) on filtration enlargement). This requires assumptions about the existence and well-behavedness of densities p⁢(y,t)𝑝𝑦𝑡p(y,t)italic_p ( italic_y , italic_t ) of the \oldtextscsde process, defined by the logarithm of the Radon-Nikodym derivative of the instantaneous measure P⁢(Yt∈dy)Psubscript𝑌𝑡𝑦\mathrm{P}(Y_{t}\in\differential y)roman_P ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y ) w.r.t. the Lebesgue measure in ℝNsuperscriptℝ𝑁\mathbb{R}^{N}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, P⁢(Yt∈dy)=p⁢(y,t)⁢dyPsubscript𝑌𝑡𝑦𝑝𝑦𝑡𝑦\mathrm{P}(Y_{t}\in\differential y)=p(y,t)\differential yroman_P ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y ) = italic_p ( italic_y , italic_t ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y222Similarly to what discussed in footnote 1, the analysis of the existence of the process adapted to ℱtYsubscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is considered in the time interval [0,T)0𝑇[0,T)[ 0 , italic_T ) (Haussmann & Pardoux, 1986). See also Appendix G..

Theorem 8.

Suppose that on (Ω,ℱ,P)ΩℱP(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Ω , caligraphic_F , roman_P ) the Markov stochastic process Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies

Yt=Y0+∫0tF′⁢(Ys,s)⁢ds+Wt,subscript𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌0superscriptsubscript0𝑡superscript𝐹′subscript𝑌𝑠𝑠𝑠subscript𝑊𝑡Y_{t}=Y_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}F^{\prime}(Y_{s},s)\differential s+W_{t},italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (13)

where {W0≤t≤T,ℱ0≤t≤TY}subscript𝑊0𝑡𝑇subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌0𝑡𝑇\{W_{0\leq t\leq T},\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{0\leq t\leq T}\}{ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is a Brownian motion and F𝐹Fitalic_F satisfies the requirements for existence and well definition of the stochastic integral (Shreve, 2004). Moreover, let 1 hold. Then, the same process admits ℛt=σ⁢(Y0≤s≤t,YT)subscriptℛ𝑡𝜎subscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡subscript𝑌𝑇\mathcal{R}_{t}=\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t},Y_{T})caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )–adapted representation

Yt=Y0+∫0tF′⁢(Ys,s)+∇Yslog⁡p⁢(YT|Ys)⁢ds+βt,subscript𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌0superscriptsubscript0𝑡superscript𝐹′subscript𝑌𝑠𝑠subscript∇subscript𝑌𝑠𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑌𝑇subscript𝑌𝑠𝑠subscript𝛽𝑡Y_{t}=Y_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}F^{\prime}(Y_{s},s)+\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{T}\,|\,Y_{% s})\differential s+\beta_{t},italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s ) + ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (14)

where p⁢(YT|Ys)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑌𝑇subscript𝑌𝑠p(Y_{T}\,|\,Y_{s})italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the density w.r.t the Lebesgue measure of the probability P⁢(YT|σ⁢(Ys))Pconditionalsubscript𝑌𝑇𝜎subscript𝑌𝑠\mathrm{P}(Y_{T}\,|\,\sigma(Y_{s}))roman_P ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_σ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), and {β0≤t≤T,ℛ0≤t≤T}subscript𝛽0𝑡𝑇subscriptℛ0𝑡𝑇\{\beta_{0\leq t\leq T},\mathcal{R}_{0\leq t\leq T}\}{ italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is a Brownian motion.

The connection between time reversal of diffusion processes and enlarged filtrations is finalized with the result of Al-Hussaini & Elliott (1987), Thm. 3.3, where it is proved how the βtsubscript𝛽𝑡\beta_{t}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT term of Equation 14 is a Brownian motion, using the techniques of time reversals of \oldtextscsdes.

Since p^⁢(y,T−t)=p⁢(y,t)^𝑝𝑦𝑇𝑡𝑝𝑦𝑡\hat{p}(y,T-t)={p}(y,t)over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( italic_y , italic_T - italic_t ) = italic_p ( italic_y , italic_t ), the enlarged filtration version of Equation 12 reads

Yt=Y0+∫0t−F⁢(Ys,T−s)+∇Yslog⁡p⁢(Ys|YT)⁢ds⏟Equivalent to ⁢H⁢(Yt,X,t)=−F⁢(Ys,T−s)+∇Yslog⁡p⁢(Ys|g⁢(X))+Wt.subscript𝑌𝑡subscript𝑌0superscriptsubscript0𝑡subscript⏟𝐹subscript𝑌𝑠𝑇𝑠subscript∇subscript𝑌𝑠𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑌𝑠subscript𝑌𝑇𝑠Equivalent to 𝐻subscript𝑌𝑡𝑋𝑡𝐹subscript𝑌𝑠𝑇𝑠subscript∇subscript𝑌𝑠𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑌𝑠𝑔𝑋subscript𝑊𝑡Y_{t}=Y_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\underbrace{-F(Y_{s},T-s)+\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{s}\,% |\,Y_{T})\differential s}_{\text{Equivalent to }H(Y_{t},X,t)=-F(Y_{s},T-s)+% \nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{s}\,|\,g(X))}+W_{t}.italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT under⏟ start_ARG - italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) + ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Equivalent to italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X , italic_t ) = - italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) + ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_g ( italic_X ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (15)

Note that the dependence of Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the latent abstractions X𝑋Xitalic_X is implicitly defined by conditioning the score term ∇Yslog⁡p⁢(Ys|YT)subscript∇subscript𝑌𝑠𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑌𝑠subscript𝑌𝑇\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{s}\,|\,Y_{T})∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by YTsubscript𝑌𝑇Y_{T}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is the “rendering” of X𝑋Xitalic_X into the observable data domain.

Clearly, Equation 15 can be reverted to the starting generative Equation 12 by mimicking the results which allowed us to go from Equation 1 to Equation 4, by noticing that 𝔼P⁢[∇Yslog⁡p⁢(YT|Ys)|ℱtY]=0subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsubscript∇subscript𝑌𝑠𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑌𝑇subscript𝑌𝑠subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑡0\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{T}\,|\,Y_{s})\,|\,\mathcal{F}^% {Y}_{t}]=0blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = 0 (informally, this is obtained since ∫∇yslog⁡p⁢(yt|ys)⁢p⁢(yt|ys)⁢dyt=∫∇ysp⁢(yt|ys)⁢dyt=0subscript∇subscript𝑦𝑠𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑡subscript𝑦𝑠𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑡subscript𝑦𝑠subscript𝑦𝑡subscript∇subscript𝑦𝑠𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑡subscript𝑦𝑠subscript𝑦𝑡0\int\nabla_{y_{s}}\log p(y_{t}\,|\,y_{s})p(y_{t}\,|\,y_{s})\differential y_{t}% =\int\nabla_{y_{s}}p(y_{t}\,|\,y_{s})\differential y_{t}=0∫ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∫ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0).

It is also important to notice that we can derive the expression for the mutual information between the measurement process and a sample from the data distribution, as follows

ℐ⁢(Y0≤s≤t;V)=ℐ⁢(Y0;V)+12⁢𝔼P⁢[∫0t‖∇Yslog⁡p⁢(Ys)−∇Yslog⁡p⁢(Ys|YT)‖2⁢ds].ℐsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡𝑉ℐsubscript𝑌0𝑉12subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0𝑡superscriptnormsubscript∇subscript𝑌𝑠𝑝subscript𝑌𝑠subscript∇subscript𝑌𝑠𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑌𝑠subscript𝑌𝑇2𝑠\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};V)=\mathcal{I}(Y_{0};V)+\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{% \mathrm{P}}\left[\int_{0}^{t}\norm{\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{s})-\nabla_{Y_{s}}% \log p(Y_{s}\,|\,Y_{T})}^{2}\differential s\right].caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_V ) = caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_V ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_ARG ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ] . (16)

Mutual information is tightly related to the classical loss function of generative diffusion models.

Furthermore, by casting the result of Equation 8 according to the forms of Equations 12 and 15, we obtain the simple and elegant expression

ℐ⁢(Y0≤s≤t;V)=ℐ⁢(Y0;V)+12⁢𝔼P⁢[∫0t‖∇Yslog⁡p⁢(YT|Ys)‖2⁢ds].ℐsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡𝑉ℐsubscript𝑌0𝑉12subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0𝑡superscriptnormsubscript∇subscript𝑌𝑠𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑌𝑇subscript𝑌𝑠2𝑠\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};V)=\mathcal{I}(Y_{0};V)+\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{% \mathrm{P}}\left[\int_{0}^{t}\norm{\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{T}\,|\,Y_{s})}^{2}% \differential s\right].caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_V ) = caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_V ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_ARG ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ] . (17)

In Appendix H, we present a specialization of our framework for the particular case of linear diffusion models, recovering the expressions for the variance-preserving and variance-exploding \oldtextscsdes that are the foundations of score-based generative models (Song et al., 2021).

4 An informal summary of the results

We shall now take a step back from the rigour of this work, and provide an intuitive summary of our results, using Figure 1 as a reference.

We begin with an illustration of \oldtextscnlf, shown on the left of the figure. We consider an observable latent abstraction X𝑋Xitalic_X and the measurement process Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which for ease of illustration we consider evolving in discrete time, i.e. Y0,Y1,…subscript𝑌0subscript𝑌1…Y_{0},Y_{1},\dotsitalic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , …, and whose joint evolution is described by Equation 1. Such interaction is shown in blue: Y3subscript𝑌3Y_{3}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depends on its immediate past Y2subscript𝑌2Y_{2}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the latent abstraction X𝑋Xitalic_X.

The a-posteriori measure process πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is updated in an iterative fashion, by integrating the flux of information. We show this in green: π1subscript𝜋1\pi_{1}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is obtained by updating π0subscript𝜋0\pi_{0}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with Y1−Y0subscript𝑌1subscript𝑌0Y_{1}-Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (the equivalent of dYtsubscript𝑌𝑡\differential Y_{t}start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). This evolution is described by Kushner’s equation, which has been derived informally from the result of Equation 6. The a-posteriori process is a sufficient statistic for the latent abstraction X𝑋Xitalic_X: for example, π3subscript𝜋3\pi_{3}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains the same information about ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ than the whole Y0,…,Y3subscript𝑌0…subscript𝑌3Y_{0},\dots,Y_{3}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (red boxes). Instead, in general, a projected statistic ⟨πt,ϕ⟩subscript𝜋𝑡italic-ϕ\langle\pi_{t},{\phi}\rangle⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ ⟩ contains less information than the whole measurement process (this is shown in orange, for time instant 2). The mutual information between all these variables is proven in Theorem 6, whereas the actual value of ℐ⁢(Y0≤s≤t;ϕ)ℐsubscript𝑌0𝑠𝑡italic-ϕ\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ ) is shown in Theorem 5.

Next, we focus on generative modelling. As by our definition, any stochastic process satisfying 1 (Y3=Vsubscript𝑌3𝑉Y_{3}=Vitalic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V, in the figure) can be used for generative purposes. Since the latent abstraction is by definition not available, it is not possible to simulate directly the dynamics using Equation 1 (dashed lines from X𝑋Xitalic_X to Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Instead, we derive a version of the process adapted to the history of Ytsubscript𝑌𝑡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT alone, together with the update of the projection ⟨πt,H⟩subscript𝜋𝑡𝐻\langle\pi_{t},H\rangle⟨ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H ⟩, which amounts to simulating Equation 10.

The update of the upper part of Equation 10, which is a particular case of Equation 6, can be interpreted as the composition of two steps: 1) (green) the update of the a-posteriori measure given new available measurements, and, 2) (orange) the projection of the whole πtsubscript𝜋𝑡\pi_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into the statistic of interest. The update of the measurement process, i.e. the lower part of Equation 10, is color-coded in blue. This is in stark contrast to the \oldtextscnlf case, as the update of e.g. Y3=Vsubscript𝑌3𝑉Y_{3}=Vitalic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V does not depend directly on X𝑋Xitalic_X. The system in Equation 10 and its simulation describes the emergence of latent world representations in \oldtextscsde-based generative models:

The theory developed in this work guarantees that the mutual information between measurements and any statistics ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ, grows as described by Theorem 5. Our framework offers a new perspective, according to which, the dynamics of \oldtextscsde-based generative models (Song et al., 2021) implicitly mimic the two steps procedure described in the box above. We claim that this is the reason why it is possible to dissect the parametric drift of such generative models and find a representation of the abstract state distribution πtsubscript𝜋𝑡{{\pi}_{t}}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, encoded into their activations. Next, we set to root our theoretical findings in experimental evidence.

5 Empirical Evidence

We complement existing empirical studies (Park et al., 2023; Kwon et al., 2023; Chen et al., 2023; Linhardt et al., 2024; Tang et al., 2023; Xiang et al., 2023; Haas et al., 2024; Sclocchi et al., 2024) that first measured the interactions between the generative process of diffusion models and latent abstractions, by focusing on a particular dataset that allows for a fine grained assessment of the influence of latent factors.

Dataset. We use the Shapes3D (Kim & Mnih, 2018) dataset, which is a collection of 64×64646464\times 6464 × 64 ray-tracing generated images, depicting simple 3D-scenes, with an object (a sphere, cube, …) placed in a space, described by several attributes (color, size, orientation). Attributes have been derived from the computer program that the ray-tracing software executed to generate the scene: these are transformed into labels associated to each image. In our experiments, such labels are the materialization of the latent abstractions X𝑋Xitalic_X we consider in this work (see § J.1 for details).

Measurement Protocols. For our experiments, we use the base \oldtextscncspp model described by  Song et al. (2021): specifically, our denoising score network corresponds to a \oldtextscu-net (Ronneberger et al., 2015). We train the unconditional version of this model from scratch, using score-matching objective. Detailed hyper-parameters and training settings are provided in § J.2. Next, we summarize three techniques to measure the emergence of latent abstractions through the lenses of the labels associated to each image in our dataset. For all such techniques, we use a specific “measurement” subset of our dataset, which we partition in 246 training, 150 validation, and 371 test examples. We use a multi-label stratification algorithm (Sechidis et al., 2011; Szymański & Kajdanowicz, 2017) to guarantee a balanced distribution of labels across all dataset splits.

Linear probing. Each image in the measurement subset is perturbed with noise, using a variance-exploding schedule (Song et al., 2021), with noise levels increasing from 0 to 1 in steps of 0.1, as shown in Figure 2. We extract several feature maps from all the linear and convolutional layers of the denoising score network, for each perturbed image, resulting in a total of 162 feature map sets for each noise level. This process yields 11 different datasets per layer, which we use to train a linear classifier (our probe) for each of these datasets, using the training subset. In these experiments, we use a batch size of 64 and adjust the learning rate based on the noise level (see § J.3). Classifier performance is optimized by selecting models based on their log-probability accuracy observed on the validation subset. The final evaluation of each classifier is conducted on the test subset. Classification accuracy, measured by the model log likelihood, is a proxy of latent abstraction emergence (Chen et al., 2023).

Mutual information estimation. We estimate mutual information between the labels and the outputs of the diffusion model across varying diffusion times, using Equation 39 (which is a specialized version of our theory for linear diffusion models, see Appendix H) and adopt the same methodology discussed by Franzese et al. (2024) to learn conditional and unconditional score functions, and to approximate the mutual information. The training process uses a randomized conditioning scheme: 33% of training instances are conditioned on all labels, 33% on a single label, and the remaining 33% are trained unconditionally. See § J.4 for additional details.

Forking. We propose a new technique to measure at which stage of the generative process, image features described by our labels emerge. Given an initial noise sample, we proceed with numerical integration of the backward \oldtextscsde (Song et al., 2021) up to time τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. At this point, we fork k𝑘kitalic_k replicas of the backward process, and continue the k𝑘kitalic_k generative pathways independently until numerical integration concludes. We use a simple classifier (a pre-trained ResNet50 (He et al., 2016) with an additional linear layer trained from scratch) to verify that labels are coherent across the k𝑘kitalic_k forks. Coherency is measured using the entropy of the label distribution output by our simple classifier on each latent factor for all the k𝑘kitalic_k forks. Intuitively: if we fork the process at time τ=0.6𝜏0.6\tau=0.6italic_τ = 0.6, and the k𝑘kitalic_k forks all end up displaying a cube in the image (entropy equals 0), this implies that the object shape is a latent abstraction that has already emerged by time τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ. Conversely, lack of coherence implies that such a latent factor has not yet influenced the generative process. Details of the classifier training and sampling procedure are provided in § J.5.

Results. We present our results in Figure 3. We note that some attributes like floor hue, wall hue and shape emerge earlier than others, which corroborates the hierarchical nature of latent abstractions, a phenomenon that is related to the spatial extent of each attribute in pixel space. This is evident from the results of linear probing, where we evaluate the performance of linear probes trained on features maps extracted from the denoiser network, and from the mutual information measurement strategy and the measured entropy of the predicted labels across forked generative pathways. Entropy decreases with τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, which marks the moment in which the generative process proceeds along k𝑘kitalic_k forks. When generative pathways converge to a unique scene with identical predicted labels (entropy reaches zero), this means that the model has committed to a specific set of latent factors. This coincides with the same noise level corresponding to high accuracy for the linear probe, and high-values of mutual information. Further ablation experiments are presented in § J.6.

6 Conclusion

Despite their tremendous success in many practical applications, a deep understanding of how \oldtextscsde-based generative models operate remained elusive. A particularly intriguing aspect of several empirical work was to uncover the capacity of generative models to create entirely new data by combining latent factors learned from examples. To the best of our knowledge, there exist no theoretical framework that attempted at describing such phenomenon.

In this work, we closed this gap, and presented a novel theory — that builds on the framework of \oldtextscnlf— to describe the implicit dynamics allowing \oldtextscsde-based generative models to tap into latent abstractions and guide the generative process. Our theory, that required advancing the standard \oldtextscnlf formulation, culminates in a new system of joint \oldtextscsdes that fully describe the iterative process of data generation. Furthermore, we derived an information-theoretic measure to study the influence of latent abstractions, which provides a concrete understanding of the joint dynamics.

To root our theory into concrete examples, we collected experimental evidence by means of novel (and established) measurement strategies, that corroborates our understanding of diffusion models. Latent abstractions emerge according to an implicitly learned hierarchy, and can appear early on in the data generation process, much earlier than what is visible in the data domain. Our theory is especially useful as it allows analyses and measurements of generative pathways, opening up opportunities for a variety of applications, including image editing, and improved conditional generation.

7 Acknowledgments

G.F. and P.M were partially funded by project MUSECOM2 - AI-enabled MUltimodal SEmantic COMmunications and COMputing, in the Machine Learning-based Communication Systems, towards Wireless AI (WAI), Call 2022, ChistERA. M.M. acknowledges the financial support of the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (AdG ELISA project, Grant agreement No. 101054746).

  • Xiang et al. (2023) Weilai Xiang, Hongyu Yang, Di Huang, and Yunhong Wang. Denoising diffusion autoencoders are unified self-supervised learners. In Proceedings of the IEEE/CVF International Conference on Computer Vision, pp.  15802–15812, 2023.
  • Xiong (2008) J. Xiong. An Introduction to Stochastic Filtering Theory. Oxford University Press, 2008.
  • Ye et al. (2022) Mao Ye, Lemeng Wu, and Qiang Liu. First hitting diffusion models for generating manifold, graph and categorical data. Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, 35:27280–27292, 2022.
  • Zeng et al. (2022) Xiaohui Zeng, Arash Vahdat, Francis Williams, Zan Gojcic, Or Litany, Sanja Fidler, and Karsten Kreis. Lion: Latent point diffusion models for 3d shape generation. In Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS), 2022.
  • Çetin & Danilova (2016) Umut Çetin and Albina Danilova. Markov bridges: Sde representation. Stochastic Processes and their Applications, 126(3):651–679, 2016. ISSN 0304-4149. doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.spa.2015.09.015. URL https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304414915002434.

Appendix A Assumptions

Assumption 2.

Whenever we mention a filtration, we assume as usual that it is augmented with the P−limit-fromP\mathrm{P}-roman_P - null sets, i.e. if the set N𝑁Nitalic_N is such that P⁢(N)=0P𝑁0\mathrm{P}(N)=0roman_P ( italic_N ) = 0, then all A⊆N𝐴𝑁A\subseteq Nitalic_A ⊆ italic_N should be in the filtration.

Assumption 3.
𝔼P⁢[∫0t‖H⁢(Ys,X,s)‖⁢ds]<∞.subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0𝑡norm𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠𝑋𝑠𝑠\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\int_{0}^{t}\norm{H(Y_{s},X,s)}\differential s]<\infty.blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_ARG italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X , italic_s ) end_ARG ∥ start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ] < ∞ . (18)
Assumption 4.
P⁢(∫0t‖𝔼P⁢[H⁢(Ys,X,s)|ℱsY]‖2⁢ds<∞)=1.Psuperscriptsubscript0𝑡superscriptnormsubscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]conditional𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠𝑋𝑠subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑌𝑠2𝑠1\mathrm{P}(\int_{0}^{t}\norm{\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[H(Y_{s},X,s)\,|\,\mathcal% {F}^{Y}_{s}]}^{2}\differential s<\infty)=1.roman_P ( ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X , italic_s ) | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s < ∞ ) = 1 . (19)

Eq 2.5 Fundamentals of Stochastic Filtering. Necessary for validity of Equation 3.

Assumption 5.
𝔼P⁢[∫0t‖H⁢(Ys,X,s)‖2⁢ds]<∞.subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0𝑡superscriptnorm𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠𝑋𝑠2𝑠\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\int_{0}^{t}\norm{H(Y_{s},X,s)}^{2}\differential s]<\infty.blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_ARG italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X , italic_s ) end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ] < ∞ . (20)

Note: this assumption implies 3 and 4. Despite it is more restrictive, it turns out that it is often easier to check.

Eq 3.19 Fundamentals of Stochastic Filtering. Necessary for validity of Theorem 3.

Assumption 6.
𝔼P⁢[exp⁡(12⁢∫0t‖H⁢(Ys,X,s)‖2⁢ds)]<∞,subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]12superscriptsubscript0𝑡superscriptnorm𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠𝑋𝑠2𝑠\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\exp{\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{t}\norm{H(Y_{s},X,s)}^{2}% \differential s}]<\infty,blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_exp ( start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_ARG italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X , italic_s ) end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s end_ARG ) ] < ∞ , (21)

and

𝔼P⁢[exp⁡(12⁢∫0t‖𝔼P⁢[H⁢(Ys,X,s)|ℛs]‖2⁢ds)]<∞,subscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]12superscriptsubscript0𝑡superscriptnormsubscript𝔼Pdelimited-[]conditional𝐻subscript𝑌𝑠𝑋𝑠subscriptℛ𝑠2𝑠\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\exp{\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{t}\norm{\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{% P}}[H(Y_{s},X,s)\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{s}]}^{2}\differential s}]<\infty,blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_exp ( start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X , italic_s ) | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s end_ARG ) ] < ∞ , (22)

Note: 6, as well as 5, are trivially verified when H𝐻Hitalic_H is bounded.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 2

We start by combining Equation 3 and Equation 1
